block.p: The Fluor Corporation said today that its quarterly earnings fell 9 percent as lower profits from its lead-producing operations more than offset better results in its core engineering and construction business.

Fluor earned $25.8 million, or 32 cents a share, on revenue of $1.8 billion for the three months that ended on Jan. 31, its first quarter. That compared with earnings of $28.2 million, or 35 cents a share, on revenue of $1.9 billion in the corresponding period a year earlier.

The Fluor Corporation said today that its quarterly earnings fell 9 percent as lower profits from its lead-producing operations more than offset better results in its core engineering and construction business.

Fluor earned $25.8 million, or 32 cents a share, on revenue of $1.8 billion for the three months that ended on Jan. 31, its first quarter. That compared with earnings of $28.2 million, or 35 cents a share, on revenue of $1.9 billion in the corresponding period a year earlier.

Fluor, the country's largest engineering and construction company, has a long history of work in the Middle East. It is expected to win big contracts to help rebuild Kuwait. Last year, it received a multibillion-dollar contract to oversee the near-doubling of Saudi oil production capacity.
Its backlog of work grew by 11 percent, to $9.7 billion, from $8.7 billion a year earlier.
"The prospect list for new engineering and construction awards remains very strong across many industries and geographic markets," said Les McCraw, Fluor's chairman and chief executive.
Fluor's stock was up 87.5 cents a share today, to $51.75 on the New York Stock Exchange.
